facts.fact: Wilhelm Steinitz was the first official World Champion (1886–94); he pioneered positional play over Romantic tactics.
Emanuel Lasker held the World Champion title for the longest time—26 years and 337 days.
Adolf Anderssen played the iconic 'Immortal Game' in 1851, sacrificing his queen and both rooks to force mate.
Lionel Kieseritzky was Anderssen’s opponent in the famous 'Immortal Game' of 1851.
Howard Staunton was the strongest player of the 1840s and popularised the Staunton-style chess pieces still used today.
Samuel Reshevsky was a child prodigy in the 1920s, playing exhibitions against masters at the age of six.
Bobby Fischer’s 1972 victory over Boris Spassky helped popularize chess worldwide.
Garry Kasparov became the youngest world champion in 1985 at the age of 22 and lost to Deep Blue in 1997.
Viswanathan Anand became India’s first grandmaster in 1988 and was World Champion five times.
Magnus Carlsen reached the highest Elo rating in history (2882) and has been World Champion since 2013.
Abhimanyu Mishra became the youngest-ever grandmaster at 12 years, 4 months, and 25 days in 2021.
Ehsan Ghaem-Maghami played the largest simultaneous exhibition in history—604 boards—in under 25 hours in 2011.
Susan Polgar won 309 of 326 games in a simultaneous exhibition in 2005.
Nicholas MacLeod lost 31 out of 38 games at the Sixth American Chess Congress in 1889, a record for most losses.
Chess originated in India during the 6th century as 'Chaturanga', meaning four divisions of the army.
The term 'checkmate' comes from the Persian 'Shāh māt', meaning 'the king is helpless' or 'the king is dead'.
Alternating light and dark squares on chessboards first appeared in Europe around 1090 AD.
The modern queen’s powerful movement was introduced in 15th-century Spain.
Castling rules were finalized in the 17th century; previously, castling required two separate moves.
The pawn's ability to move two squares on its first move appeared around 1280 in Spain.
The Staunton chess set, designed in 1849, became the standard for tournament play.
The first international chess tournament was held in London in 1851, organized by Howard Staunton.
Chess clocks were first used in tournament play in the 1880s, replacing hourglasses.
Claude Shannon estimated the number of possible chess games to be about 10^120, known as 'Shannon's Number'.
The longest theoretically possible chess game under modern rules is 5,949 moves.
The longest recorded game in chess history lasted 269 moves and over 20 hours (Nikolic–Arsovic, 1989).
The latest first capture in a professional game occurred on move 94 (Williams–Rogoff, 1969).
The shortest decisive professional game ended in just three moves (Đorđević–Kovačević, 1984).
The Lewis Chessmen, discovered in Scotland, date back to the 12th century and are among the oldest known sets.
Judith Polgar became the youngest grandmaster at the time in 1991, breaking Bobby Fischer’s record.
Paul Morphy, often considered a chess prodigy, dominated the mid-19th century and retired early.
José Raúl Capablanca was World Champion from 1921 to 1927 and known for his intuitive endgame mastery.
Alexander Alekhine was the first World Champion to die while holding the title.
Mikhail Tal, the 'Magician from Riga', was known for his daring and sacrificial attacking style.
Tigran Petrosian, World Champion from 1963–1969, was known for his fortress-like defensive style.
Vladimir Kramnik defeated Garry Kasparov in 2000 and introduced deep preparation against the Berlin Defense.
Anatoly Karpov became World Champion without a match in 1975 when Fischer refused to defend his title.
Jan Timman was known as the 'Best of the West' during the Cold War chess era.
Hou Yifan is the strongest female chess player of the 21st century century and a former Women’s World Champion.
Nona Gaprindashvili was the first woman to be awarded the Grandmaster title by FIDE in 1978.
Ulf Andersson was renowned for his mastery of slow positional grinds in the 1980s.
Chess was banned in France in 1254 by King Louis IX as it was seen as a distraction.
Napoleon Bonaparte was an avid chess player, though not particularly strong.
Chess appeared in the first printed book on games, 'Libro de los Juegos', commissioned by Alfonso X in 1283.
Benjamin Franklin wrote an essay called 'The Morals of Chess' in 1786 promoting its intellectual benefits.
FIDE (Fédération Internationale des Échecs) was founded in 1924 in Paris to oversee international chess.
Chess960, or Fischer Random, was invented by Bobby Fischer to eliminate opening preparation.
The ‘en passant’ rule for pawn captures was standardized in the 15th century.
The Berlin Defense became famous after Kramnik used it to defeat Kasparov in 2000.
